article.headline: California 76, UCLA 62
article.story: BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) -- Amit Tamir made a commitment to his California teammates to play harder -- he thought he let them down with a lack of energy last game. On Saturday, Tamir impressed everyone with his high effort level, and Leon Powe just fed off it. Powe had 19 points and 14 rebounds and the Golden Bears won consecutive games for the first time this season, defeating UCLA 76-62. "I was doing a lot of things, so it was my best all-around game," Powe said. "The coaches kept stressing we've got to rebound. I was trying to think every shot is good. Fortunately some of them went in." Tamir added 19 points, five rebounds and three assists for the Bears, who beat the Bruins for the fourth straight time in Berkeley before a sellout crowd of 11,877 -- the first time Cal (8-8, 4-3 Pac-10) sold out Haas Pavilion this season. "It's just a mind-set at the beginning of the game," Tamir said. "I wanted to come in and attack and try to hype the team. We just wanted to build on the win we had on Thursday. We have a very hungry team and we're not satisfied with the way the season's been going." Dijon Thompson scored 17 points for UCLA (9-6, 5-3), whose only previous conference losses had been to No. 2 Stanford and 14th-ranked Arizona. Trevor Ariza added 11 points and eight rebounds and T.J. Cummings 12 points and six boards. Powe, Cal's leading scorer and rebounder who has eight double-doubles, took over the game in crunch time, scoring 12 points in the second half. He had a key putback with 6:15 left and another basket moments later, then swished a long jumper with 2:43 remaining. Powe took the ball hard to the hoop to draw fouls late in the game and went 7-of-16 from the free throw line. "He's a warrior," Tamir said. "He can play hard. He was the aggressor. When he's in that mode, just step aside and enjoy the show." The Bears, who start three freshmen and a sophomore and have had trouble establishing any consistency, beat USC 63-62 on Thursday. They were 22-of-38 at the line Saturday and shot 45.3 percent from the field. Cal players wore small black patches on the front of their uniforms with "AL 31" in memory of women's basketball player Alisa Lewis, who died Monday from bacterial meningitis, an infection of the covering of the brain and spinal cord. "It's just important to put life in perspective," coach Ben Braun said. "You honor her passing, honor her spirit and move on. You have a lot of sympathy for what they go through." Ayinde Ubaka broke a 38-all tie on a four-point play with 13:26 left after UCLA's Ryan Hollins pushed him down for the foul on his 3-pointer from the wing. It was a game of three-point plays, and Ubaka had another with 8:33 to go that gave Cal a 51-47 lead. He finished with 13 points. Cal hopes it can build some momentum from the sweep of the Southern California schools. "If you're in the Pac-10 there are no guarantees," Braun said. "Very few teams get back-to-back wins. When you do that in this league, you've done something." UCLA's 7-foot center Michael Fey began the game guarding Powe, who wore a bulky brace on his troublesome left knee, but the Bruins rotated several players on the talented freshman and double-teamed him at times. "He took the game over just by going to the glass," UCLA coach Ben Howland said. "He was just strong, aggressive and tough, and he wanted it more." Everything went Cal's way early -- even a jump ball call that was changed to a Cal possession after a huddle by the officials. The Bears started 5-for-7 from the field, including 4-of-4 from 3-point range, to take a 14-2 lead 3:55 into the game. The Bruins didn't lead until Josiah Johnson made one free throw with .2 seconds left before halftime to give UCLA a 31-30 lead.
